{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3134594,"name":"Mary Alice","username":"mac55","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/57b2e6/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-26T23:20:37.934Z","cooked":"

Does anyone have a MaxPlanetary System Kit 75:1 and Max 90 Degree gearbox team 5503 can borrow until we get ours from Rev in March? OR we’re happy to buy, just let us know. OR any suggestion for an alternate we can use on the EveryBot. THANKS!

Versa planetary into a versa right angle.

Armabot has a right angle as well.

This might hold up.

Not sure how the mounting would look. I haven’t checked the Everybot CAD.

I think this is lighter duty than the similar rev product, so YMMV.

andymark.com

1:1 LJ Bevel Box with 0.5 in. Hex Output Shaft

The LJ Bevel Box is a right angle gearbox using steel bevel gears, designed to integrate with a CIM Motor (am-0255), CIM-Sim (am-0932), 57 Sport, NEO, or CIM Sport. This setup allows for the use of a gearbox or CIM motor in locations where you...

I was looking at this too. You could use an 80:1 Sport Gearbox and this, but The bevels are quite small. Can @NathanNFM or someone else at andymark say if they would recommend this setup?

We’ve used that AM 90 degree box on an intake before and it worked well, although it was pretty heavy. Not sure how it would handle a more torque driven ntensive application.

Funny you should mention that. I was just working on a variant of this today that will accept a pass through hex shaft for the Everybot application. Hopefully it’ll be on the website by next week, but the current gearbox is modifiable into that with just a hex bearing. With the current version you just get a $20 shaft you don’t need.
I tested it to ~40 ft lb before a gear tooth broke.

This is awesome! I have a system kit 75:1, but not the 90 degree gearbox. Can I just use this in place (will it fit?)?

Yep! Looks like the only tricky bit will be which hex shaft to pick for the Max planetary output. The max length without interfering with the cross hex shaft is ~1 7/16" long, but it look like the closest length without going over on McMaster is 1 1/4" Which should be enough to drive the gear. Alternatively you could space the MAX off from the bevel housing by ~1/16" and use the 1.5" long shaft from McMaster.

Kind of off topic but seeing as you use solidworks at Andymark would it be possible to have the .sldprt and solidworks assembly files on your website in addition to the step files?
